ygData.subject: Re: Standard network XML dialect.
ygData.msgSnippet: ... I think the XML stuff is cool.  The only disadvantage is that the genomes in XML are difficult to read or edit.  For example, the format I ve been using

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <blue5432@y...> wrote:
> --- Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> > Has anyone considered using XML for storing NN
> > definitions? 
> 
> Why...yes. :)
> 
> Our Java implementation persists chromosomes in XML. 
> Here's an example of a generational champion from a
> successful XOR run:
> 
> <chromosome id="2853" primary-parent-id="2763">
> <neuron id="0" type="IN"/>
> <neuron id="1" type="IN"/>
> <neuron id="2" type="IN"/>
> <neuron id="3" type="OUT"/>
> <connection id="4" src-id="0" dest-id="3"
> weight="-1.3731676929130425"/>
> <connection id="5" src-id="1" dest-id="3"
> weight="-1.208831769841949"/>
> <connection id="6" src-id="2" dest-id="3"
> weight="-0.853548931074944"/>
> <neuron id="16" type="HID"/>
> <connection id="17" src-id="0" dest-id="16"
> weight="5.635234190131094"/>
> <connection id="18" src-id="16" dest-id="3"
> weight="2.7205467728011365"/>
> <connection id="34" src-id="2" dest-id="16"
> weight="-3.3648746983653126"/>
> <connection id="40" src-id="1" dest-id="16"
> weight="4.812986451760211"/>
> </chromosome>
> 
> It's pretty self-explanatory.  This chromosome is a
> mutated clone (it has a single parent).  Chromosomes
> that result from crossover have a primary and
> secondary parent.
> 
> We also use XML to persist information about runs, and
> we use XSL style sheets to convert the XML into SVG
> for display purposes.
> 

I think the XML stuff is cool.  The only disadvantage is that the
genomes in XML are difficult to read or edit.  For example, the format
I've been using for genome files (which is completely ad hoc) is
easier to read or edit:

genomestart 1
trait 1 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 
node 1 0 1 1
node 2 0 1 1
node 3 0 1 1
node 4 0 1 1
node 5 0 1 1
node 6 0 1 1
node 7 0 1 1
node 8 0 1 1
node 9 0 1 1
node 10 0 1 1
node 11 0 1 1
node 12 0 1 1
node 13 0 1 3
node 14 0 0 2
node 15 0 0 2
node 16 0 0 2
gene 1 1 14 -0.242932 0 1 -0.242932 1
gene 1 2 14 -0.665275 0 2 -0.665275 1
gene 1 3 14 -0.690939 0 3 -0.690939 1
gene 1 4 14 0.313999 0 4 0.313999 1
gene 1 5 14 0.977945 0 5 0.977945 1
gene 1 6 14 0.631592 0 6 0.631592 1
gene 1 7 14 0.561102 0 7 0.561102 1
gene 1 8 14 -0.900819 0 8 -0.900819 1
gene 1 9 14 -0.609741 0 9 -0.609741 1
gene 1 10 14 -0.16686 0 10 -0.16686 1
gene 1 11 14 0.882974 0 11 0.882974 1
gene 1 12 14 -0.351466 0 12 -0.351466 1
gene 1 13 14 -0.843264 0 13 -0.843264 1
gene 1 1 15 -0.943675 0 14 -0.943675 1
gene 1 2 15 0.608334 0 15 0.608334 1
gene 1 3 15 0.745187 0 16 0.745187 1
gene 1 4 15 0.445595 0 17 0.445595 1
gene 1 5 15 -0.934685 0 18 -0.934685 1
gene 1 6 15 0.0476139 0 19 0.0476139 1
gene 1 7 15 -0.474238 0 20 -0.474238 1
gene 1 8 15 0.506081 0 21 0.506081 1
gene 1 9 15 -0.708393 0 22 -0.708393 1
gene 1 10 15 -0.512977 0 23 -0.512977 1
gene 1 11 15 -0.739124 0 24 -0.739124 1
gene 1 12 15 -0.235913 0 25 -0.235913 1
gene 1 13 15 -0.571936 0 26 -0.571936 1
gene 1 1 16 0.688133 0 27 0.688133 1
gene 1 2 16 0.24045 0 28 0.24045 1
gene 1 3 16 0.564656 0 29 0.564656 1
gene 1 4 16 0.330407 0 30 0.330407 1
gene 1 5 16 0.56039 0 31 0.56039 1
gene 1 6 16 0.894438 0 32 0.894438 1
gene 1 7 16 0.130351 0 33 0.130351 1
gene 1 8 16 -0.300949 0 34 -0.300949 1
gene 1 9 16 0 0 35 0 1
gene 1 10 16 0 0 36 0 1
gene 1 11 16 0.532546 0 37 0.532546 1
gene 1 12 16 0.279077 0 38 0.279077 1
gene 1 13 16 0.475364 0 39 0.475364 1
genomeend 1

It's easy to delete a gene, see the nodes and
genes, see the historical markings (the numbers 
increasing  from 1 to 39 in the gens). The
format also allows comments in C-style, so 
genes can be commented out:

/* gene 1 10 16 0 0 36 0 1 */

And later reinstated (for ablation studies).

Anyway, XML has some great properties and uses, so
I am not arguing against XML.  But what I think
would be especially cool would be if there was
a conversion function both ways between NEAT-XML 
and NEAT-traditional genome styles.  That way,
you could get the benefits of both formats, 
as well as get backward-compatibility with all the 
genome files people already have in the old format.

ken
